journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part I: Journal of Systems and Control Engineering

title-group.article-title: Robust partial control design for non-linear control systems: a guidance application

article-meta.aff: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Shiraz University of Technology, Shiraz, Iran
Control and Intelligent Processing Center of Excellence, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: *School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Shiraz University of Technology, Shiraz, Iran email: binazadeh@sutech.ac.ir

abstract.p: In this paper, a general approach for robust partial stabilization of uncertain non-linear systems is presented. In this approach, the non-linear dynamic system is divided into two subsystems, called the first and the second subsystems. This division is done based on the required stability properties of the system’s states. The reduced input vector (the vector that includes components of the input vector appearing in the first subsystem) is designed to asymptotically stabilize the first subsystem. The proposed scheme is then applied for designing a guidance law as a potential application. Indeed, the paper presents a new approach to the missile guidance problem and shows that asymptotic stability behaviour is not realistic for all states of the guidance system. The effectiveness of the proposed guidance law in interception of manoeuvring targets is demonstrated analytically and through computer simulations.

sec.title: 1 Introduction
sec.p: For many engineering problems like ball-and-beam systems and suspension systems [1, 2], application of Lyapunov stability theory is required. However, there are other physical systems, such as inertial navigation systems, spacecraft stabilization via gimballed gyroscopes or flywheels, electromagnetic [3–9], where partial stability is necessary. In the mentioned applications, while the plant may be unstable in the standard sense, it is however partially asymptotically stable. This means that the plant is stable with respect to only part of the system’s state.

In spite of various research papers in the field of partial stability applications, there are only a few dealing with partial control design and the advantages of partial control are not fully recognized. Furthermore, most of the papers do not propose a general framework to design a partially stabilizing controller for non-linear systems. In reference [4], the design of a partial controller was done for an Euler dynamic system. References [6] and [7] dealt with several types of partial stabilization and control problems, such as permanent rotations of a rigid body, relative equilibrium of a satellite, and stationary motions of a gimballed gyroscope. Application of partial stabilization to achieve chaos synchronization was investigated in references [8] and [9].

In the present paper, the problem of robust partial stabilization of non-linear dynamic systems in the presence of uncertainties and external disturbances is considered. It is shown that partial control provides the possibility to convert the control problem into a simpler one by reducing the control input variables. For this purpose, the system’s state is separated into two parts with respect to their stability properties and accordingly the non-linear dynamic system is divided into two subsystems, hereafter referred to as the ‘first’ and the ‘second’ subsystems. The reduced control input vector (the vector that includes components of the input vector which appear in the first subsystem) is designed in such a way as to guarantee asymptotic stability of the non-linear system with respect to the first part of the state vector.

The proposed scheme is then applied to design a guidance law for a missile against manoeuvring targets. An effective approach to deal with manoeuvrable targets is to apply a robust guidance scheme. However, many existing robust guidance laws are obtained based on Lyapunov theorems on asymptotic stability or exponential stability of all states [10–19]. In the present paper it is shown that, practically, such behaviour is not realistic for all states of the guidance system. Furthermore, the guidance problem has a characteristic property: the missile should intercept a highly manoeuvring target within a finite interception time, sometimes only a few seconds. Therefore in the present paper a guidance law is designed based on partial control to guarantee the mentioned characteristic.

The remainder of the paper is arranged as follows. First, the preliminaries on partial stability are given in section 2. In section 3, the theorems for robust partial control design are presented and explained in detail. Next, in section 4, the proposed approach is applied to design a guidance law. Finally, conclusions are made in section 5.

sec.p:
It is important to note that this partial stability definition (which is given in reference [5]) is different from past definitions of partial stability [3, 6]. In past definitions, it is required that
F 1
( 0 , 0 ) = 0
and
F 2
( 0 , 0 ) = 0
. Also, the initial condition of the whole system should be in the neighbourhood of the origin which is not required in Definition 1. The main advantage of considering the condition
F 1
( 0 ,
x 2
) = 0
for every x2 is that it provides the possibility to investigate the partial stability even if part of a system’s states goes to infinity. Using this fact, Chellaboina and Haddad [5] present the unification of partial stability theory for autonomous systems and stability theory for non-linear time-varying systems. This unification allows the stability theory of time-varying systems to be presented as a special case of autonomous partial stability theory.

sec.title: 3 An Approach For Robust Partial Control Design
sec.p: This section presents a feasible design algorithm for robust partial stabilization of non-linear systems. First, partial control for the nominal system is designed and then an additional feedback control is designed so that the overall control law guarantees partial stabilization in the presence of matching uncertainties and disturbances.

The above approach for handling uncertainties and disturbances stems from the Lyapunov redesign method [20]. Assumptions like conditions (21) and (24) are considered in reference [20] for stabilization of all states while in the current paper this idea is used partially, to guarantee stabilization of only part of the states in the presence of matching uncertainties and disturbances.

sec.title: 4 Application of Partial Control to the Missile Guidance Problem
sec.p: In this section, a new approach to designing a missile guidance law based on the proposed partial control theorem is presented.

sec.title: 4.1 Missile/target kinematics model
sec.p:
A two-dimensional air-to-air engagement is shown in Fig. 1. The vehicles are modelled as point masses. The relative motion between the missile (M) and the target (T) is described by planar lines of sight (LOS; lines which connect the target to the missile at each moment) in coordinate system
( r , θ )
, with the origin fixed on the location of the missile. The dynamic equations are given by [16]

where r is the relative distance between the missile and the target, θ is the LOS angle, and
ω =
(
ω r
,
ω θ
)
T
and
u =
(
u r
,
u θ
)
T
are the acceleration vectors of target and missile, respectively. It is assumed that both ur and uθ are available. By considering
[

] = [

]

Initial conditions of the terminal phase are usually expressed such in a way that
r 0
> 0
and
V
r 0
< 0
(as assumed in the present work). This means that the target is in front of the missile and the missile is approaching it.

sec.title: 4.2 Desirable behaviours for each state
sec.p:
For the interception, it is sufficient that r(t) becomes zero in an instant (
r (
t f
) = 0
where tf is interception time) and there is no need for r(t) to asymptotically converge to zero. In other words, asymptotic convergence is not an ideal behaviour for r(t). It should be noted that asymptotic convergence behaviour means that the missile initially approaches the target very fast; however, near the target, the relative distance reduces so slowly that the missile touches the target in an infinite time. It is evident that such behaviour is not a desirable behaviour in missile guidance, in which the missile is supposed to hit the target with a non-zero speed in a finite time. For this purpose, it is sufficient for the relative radial speed between the missile and the target to satisfy the following proposition.
In order to intercept the target within a finite time interval, it is sufficient to have

r(t) is positive and continuous. Consequently, to reach a zero value, i.e. zero-miss distance, within a finite time, it should decrease from its value at
t 1
( <
t f
)
down to a zero value at tf. Inequality (29) implies
r ( t ) − r (
t 1
) ≤ − ζ ( t −
t 1
)
, which shows that r(t) reduces within the time interval
[
t 1
t ]
. Since it is desirable to have
r (
t f
) = 0
, then
Hence, the expectation is that Vr satisfies Proposition 1. In other words, the convergence and stability of this state are not under consideration. ▪

A common approach in relevant papers is to regulate Vr to a negative constant c. Although this approach guarantees the interception of the non-manoeuvring target within a finite time, it is not efficient for intercepting a highly manoeuvring target in an acceptable interception time. In such a case, to improve the performance, c should vary with time; however, to determine it, the manoeuvring model of the target should be known to the missile, which is not always practically possible [14].

Regarding the other state variable, i.e. Vθ, asymptotic convergence behaviour is desirable. An appropriate guidance law, in addition to decreasing the relative distance, must keep the LOS angular rates as small as possible [19]. This means that
V θ
→ 0
is desirable. Therefore, the state vector may be separated into
x 1
=
V θ
and
x 2
= [ r

1

V θ
may be achieved by
u θ
. In the meantime, the appropriate behaviour of x2 could be obtained by ur.

Since discontinuous controllers suffer from chattering, one way to alleviate this problem is to consider an approximation of the signum function by a saturation function with a high slope (1/ε).
Consequently, the guidance law (44) guarantees intercepting the manoeuvring target within a finite interception and zero-miss distance

In the proposed guidance law, the target acceleration is treated as an external disturbance and this law requires only the target’s acceleration limit; therefore there is no need for exact information on the target’s acceleration. A conservative estimation of this limit causes an increase in the energy of the control signal and, also, an oscillation in the states which degrades the performance.

sec.title: 4.4 Computer simulation
sec.p: Numerical simulations are performed to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed robust non-linear guidance law (44). The initial conditions of engagement are specified as r0 = 5000 m, Vr0 = − 300 m/s, and Vθ0 = 100 m/s. A highly manoeuvring target with the following acceleration vector is considered

The initial conditions in the inertia frame of the missile and the target are given by
x M
( 0 ) =
y M
( 0 ) = 0 m
(for the missile) and
x T
( 0 ) = 5000 cos
θ 0
m
,
y T
( 0 ) = 5000 sin
θ 0
m
,
v
T x
( 0 ) = − 200 m/s
, and
v
T y
( 0 ) = 0 m/s
(for the target), where θ0 is set equal to π/6. In addition, the constant N is chosen 0.1, while ηr and ηθ are set to be 200. Also, ε = 1 and σ = 0.05 are selected.

Figures 2(a) to (c) show the relative distance r between the missile and the target, the relative radial speed Vr, and the relative tangential speed Vθ. As expected, each state has its desirable behaviour mentioned in section 4.2.

caption.p: Time evolution of: (a) relative distance, r; (b) relative radial speed, Vr; (c) relative tangential speed Vθ

sec.p: In Figs 3(a) to (c), the proposed robust guidance law (44) is compared with the sliding-mode guidance law presented by the following guidance command [16]

caption.p: (a) Trajectory of the missile and the target; (b) tangential guidance command, uθ; (c) radial guidance command, ur

sec.p:
The sliding-mode guidance law has been compared with some existing robust guidance laws in reference [16]. This guidance law has gained the better performance in terms of interception time and control effort compared with other existing guidance laws; however, Figs 3(a) to (c) show that the guidance law proposed in the present paper achieves better performance compared with that of reference [16] in terms of interception time and control effort. Suppose N1 = 4, c = − 800, ε = 1,
η r
=
η θ
= 200
, N = 0.1, and σ = 0.05. The initial conditions of engagement and the initial conditions in the inertia frame of the missile and the target are the same as before. Figure 3(a) illustrates trajectories of the missile and the target, where C1 and C2 are the collision points for the guidance laws (44) and (46), respectively. The interception time is 7.26 s for law (44) and 8.38 s for law (46). Figure 3(b) shows that the proposed guidance law (44) requires less tangential control effort than that of the sliding-mode guidance law (46). Also, Fig. 3(c) demonstrates that the amount of changes of radial control effort for law (44) is less than that of law (46).

sec.title: 5 Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, a general approach for stabilization of uncertain non-linear systems with respect to part of a system’s state was proposed. It was shown that the control input vector can be simplified by reducing its control variables, and the reduced input vector was designed in such a way that asymptotic stabilization of part of the system’s state in the presence of uncertainties and external disturbances was achieved. Since in some applications it is desirable for other states to satisfy specific constraints, the remaining components of the input vector may be designed to satisfy those constraints. The proposed strategy was applied to design a guidance law. Indeed, the paper presented a new approach to the guidance problem. It was demonstrated that in a realistic approach to missile guidance, each state must have a special behaviour to yield interception of a manoeuvring target. Numerical simulations showed the effectiveness of the proposed approach in the guidance application.
